section.name: NURSING CARE OF THE OLDER ADULT: THEORY/CLINICAL

comments:
This course is an overview that integrates selected theoretical information into
research-based nursing care of the older adult. The overview includes principles of
gerontological care; specialized ns; assessment of the older adult; effects of physiological
aging changes on health and illness; psychosocial problems associated with aging, with
special attention to family issues; pharmacological, nutritional, and ethical
considerations; and the settings where older persons are the recipients of care. The
clinical application takes place in an acute care setting and emphasizes transitional care
for older adults across the health care continuum.
Students felt that the class presented "important" information, but were somewhat
disappointed with how it was presented during lectures, which were described as
"disorganized" and "not engaging." Many students also commented on the irrelevance of
certain readings and lack of consistency between lecture material and the test questions.
Many students considered Professor Kagan distant and difficult to follow. Some
students noted that Professor Kagan did not make an effort to assist struggling students.
Students found the instructors' expectations "unrealistic" and not clearly defined.
Students felt that the course required too much work and that the readings were
not especially applicable. Students felt that the exams were "vague" and worth too much
of the grade.

section.name: NURSING CARE OF THE OLDER ADULT: THEORY/CLINICAL

comments:
This course is an overview that integrates selected theoretical information into
research-based nursing care of the older adult. The overview includes principles of
gerontological care; specialized ns; assessment of the older adult; effects of physiological
aging changes on health and illness; psychosocial problems associated with aging, with
special attention to family issues; pharmacological, nutritional, and ethical
considerations; and the settings where older persons are the recipients of care. The
clinical application takes place in an acute care setting and emphasizes transitional care
for older adults across the health care continuum.
The majority of students were disappointed and frustrated with the poor
organization of the course. Many felt unprepared for the assignments and tests because
the expectations were not clearly explained. One student states “it was very frustrating for
students to have elevated expectations without the infrastructure support.”
Students were disappointed with the lack of support of the course directors. Some
felt they were insensitive to the students’ needs and did not recognize and try to ramify
why students were struggling.
This course is a clinical course required for nursing students, typically taken in
junior year.

section.name: NURSING CARE OF THE OLDER ADULT: THEORY/CLINICAL

comments:
This course is an overview that integrates selected theoretical information into
research-based nursing care of the older adult. The overview includes principles of
gerontological care; specialized ns; assessment of the older adult; effects of physiological
aging changes on health and illness; psychosocial problems associated with aging, with
special attention to family issues; pharmacological, nutritional, and ethical
considerations; and the settings where older persons are the recipients of care. The
clinical application takes place in an acute care setting and emphasizes transitional care
for older adults across the health care continuum.
Many students expressed disappointment with the course. Overall they felt that
the lecture was ineffective in conveying the majority of the information essential to the
course and had to find the information independently, outside of class. Lectures were
described as “scattered and difficult to follow.” Furthermore, the exams failed to
accurately reflect the lecture material. Assignments were viewed by many as “busy
work.”
The professors for the course were considered as somewhat inaccessible. Students
commented that they felt uncomfortable asking questions during the lecture and were
unable to get the direction they needed. This lack of direction extended to the paper and
exam assignments as well. Many students felt they had to rely on each other, without the
professor to turn to.
This course was widely considered quite difficult. Long reading assignments
required a serious time commitment. Following disorganized lectures, students generally
felt unprepared for the exams and could not get a thorough grasp on the type of questions
asked. Furthermore, some felt the tests were graded “harshly”.

section.name: CLINIC: PRESBY ACE UNIT - Acute Care For Elderly

comments:
Laboratory Component to NURS-270-001. This course is an overview that
integrates selected theoretical information into research-based nursing care of the older
adult. The overview includes principles of gerontological care; assessment of the older
adult; effects of physiological aging changes on health and illness; psychosocial problems
associated with aging, with special attention to family issues; pharmacological,
nutritional, and ethical considerations; and the settings where older persons are the
recipients of care. The clinical application takes place in an acute care setting and
emphasizes transitional care for older adults across the health care continuum.
Overall, students for the most part found this course to be “incredible” and “very
valuable.” However, several decried the course for its lack of organization citing
confusion over the syllabus, grading scale, and lack of “continuity” among different lab
groups.
Students praised Iorianni-Cimbak “communicated the material to the best of her
ability.” However, several chided her “inconsistency” and lack of timeliness in
communications.
Overall, students felt that there a lot of “variability” in the grading between lab
groups, and the “vague” nature of the course’s structure was confusing to many students.
